S: Tart and sour cherries hit right from the start, a bit of musty funk and acietic vinegar. 
T: Delicious cherries. Simultaneously sweet, tart and sour. Waves of flavor sensations come at you with each sip. A nice underlying funk, and musty oak -- that quintessential cantillon vibe is definitely here. Some general acidic notes round things out. I am a fan of aged krieks even though they start to lose some of the cherry flavor. This was divine.
M: Medium bodied with good gentle carbonation. Smooth, almost juice like. Quite puckering.
O: I had one glass, and easily could of had a second, but this is a sip and savor beer!

2007 Bottle, at Jimmys no. 43 during the Lovullo Sour Tasting Session. Pours a light, cherry-red-brown-pink with a filmy white head. Tart fruit aroma. Flavor is sour cherry with light sweetness. Mild earthen bitters on the tail, as well as distinct dryness. Some ripe cherry character and even some nuttiness. Tingly mouthfeel. Very nice.

Sampled at the Secret Summit- probably a 2007 edition given its softness and not too intense sourness. Pours an unreal, super cloudy, vibrant, deep pink/purple with a dense, light purple head that has excellent retention and lace. Aroma is light band-aid that quickly moves to baked cherry pie, freshly baked/burnt sweet cherries. Incredible. Taste is tart, not too sour, full of cherry pie. Really has no flaws at all. Soft, lactic, cherry yogurt palate. 9/5/9/5/15=4.1   750mL 2007. Pours perfectly with a creamy pink, thin head that lasts throughout. Nose is just so awesome. Soft, tart, cherries, cherry pie, raspberry yogurt. Taste is similar: a play off raspberries and sour cherries with such a soft, beautiful body it really is not even fair. This is definitely the perfect kriek. I want some everyday.

Bright red color with a bubbly pink head. Very fruity aroma. Cherries, of course, and smells a little like vinegar. Flavor is sweet but balanced, tart, maybe a little funk. Carbonation is right on. Classic.

Poured a very cloudy red with a small white head that sticks around for quite some time as lacing. Smells of a typical Cantillon Kriek. Tastes a bit more sour than usual, but very good. If this wasnt as pricey as it was I would buy it as often as I saw it. Which isnt too often either. Finishes tart, refreshing, and longing for more.

Have had this multiple times and multiple vintages, finally rating it.

Pours deep dark ruby with big pink fluffy bubbly head. 

Aroma is dominated by cherry, but has huge grapefruit and lemon along with a little vanilla and a touch of funk.

Great sweet fruit up front and then a fantastic sour cherry finish. I really cant describe it much better than that.

The Lou Pepe Kriek is medium bodied and almost like thick fruit juice, but the great carbonation balances it well. Slight butteriness but always drinkable.

Overall an exceptional beer that Ill be drinking many times in the future and a great example of a kriek.

The bottle is a testament to quality.  The dated cork capped with a pop top is a nice touch.  It pours bright red with a pink fizzy head.  The aroma is interesting with a strong nose of cherries, and fresh cooked pasta.  The flavor is surprisingly well balanced between the sweet and the tart, and is quite smooth, but is quite shocking for the first few sips.  The finish is rather quick, but the tartness fades leaving behind a fantastic fruitiness.  The mouthfeel is like silk gently rolling over the tongue, very smooth.  This is a very impressive lambic.

Bottle at home. Hazy purple pour, thin pink head. Aroma of brett and cherries, some dust, cheese and fruits. Flavor is nice and sour with some fruity cherries and apple. Some hints of blackcurrant and red wine. Lively carbonation. Nice brew.

On tap. Pours dark red with a large pink head; sour dark cherryish aroma; flavor is only moderate sour, unsweet cherryish; body is medium with moderate, lively carbonation. Theres not much to say about this, really, but that doesnt mean Im trying to hide my love away. The only thing is that I actually expected this to be even more powerful.

06 and 04 side by side at sour fest.   hazy plum pour with a pinkish frothy head.   very fruity raspberry. light basement funk.  fruit is very prominent.  light water wheat note.  solid.  really clean fruit.  nice, dry.  aroma sharp cherry acid.  raspberry air fresheners as well for all the playas out there.

A: The pour is blood red in color with a big pink head that dies down to a thin cap.

S: Lots of cherry skins and bugs. A wet straw and musty funk, along with wet oak. Quite a bit of lactic acidity as well.

T: The cherries offer both some sweetness along with a sour note and plenty of tannins (fruit skin flavor as well). The lactic tartness is there, but not quite as overwhelmingly acidic as some lambics. The brett is funky and drying, just the way I like it.

M: The body is medium with a low, rolling carbonation and a nice dry finish.

D: The cherries stand out wonderfully and help to balance out the base lambic, it would seem. Pleasantly sour without being overly so. Well worth the exorbitant cost.

On tap at Sour Fest. 2004 and 2006 side by side! Pours a cloudy red hue with a small white head. The aroma was tart wood and vinegar. The 2004 was much smoother; rich fruit, sweet yeasty malts, tart and a very active mouthfeel. The 06 was more agressive; quite sour and less complex. Both were amazing. Tart and lively.

Huge thanks go out to Rcielsa for opening a 2001 vintage of this at the Travel Lodge.

Pours a deep dark cherry red with a two finger frothy redish pink head that has very good retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap. Sporadic spots of lacing left behind. Comletely opaque with slightly visible carbonation bubbling up.

Earthy funk aroma with a blast of uber fresh tart dark cherries. It shocking how prevalent the frut still is in the nose. Lots of earthy oak and barnyard horsey funk with hits of bandaid and sweatsock but again the sweet smelling cherries balance things out nicely.

Medium body with lots of tart sour funk and the perfect amount of acidity. Again as in the aroma, the flavor is bursting with luscious tart dark cherries. I cant understand how the frut has held up so well but although this beer is funky as hell the cherries still dominate. We also sampled an 05 Lou Pepe Framboise and it was nowhere near as complex. The fruit was almost completely faded and it was insanely funky. This beer has hints of earthy oak and plenty of sour barnyard funk that balance out the cherries and sugar added but again the cherries are prominent. This beer has developed very well into a delicious, complex lambic and the mouth puckering finish left me salivating for more. Highly recommended!

Bottle said 2005 Cork 2007 Maroon pour pinkish white head .... aroma of sour cherries and oak ...... sour cherries and dry oaky taste light lacing very well done has aged well and balanced .... paid a bit much for it $35 but it was worth it .... like a nice wine loved it

Bottle. Leakage over the cork under the cap. Cork came out in 4 separate pieces, the last one with a good pop. Pours a dark red. Relatively still with a full bodied surprisingly creamy palate. Aroma of cherries seemed stronger than the flavour. Good thing I bought a couple extra to put down. Not sure if it is too young or I am expecting a lot more. Very little sourness. Quiet sipper.

Medium pink coarseish head. Intensely red body. Barnyard cherry aroma with cheesy leather and peppery cinnamon notes. Very harmonic. Sour graps, wood and cinnamon taste with leathery cherry and cheese notes. Thin body. Amazingly harmonic. Sharpish mouthfeel. Dry-sour fruity cherry cinnamon and lime aftertaste with yoghurty wooden notes. Excellent! Keep discovering new things in it as I drink. Amazing harmony. Love it! (0.75l bottle at Håndverkerstuene, Oslo.)
True classic. Deep red color. Nose is cherry pie and citrus. Taste is roasted cherry. Dry finish. Rated 8/1/08

Bottle.

A - Burgundy color with an slightly above average sized, bubbly light pink head. About average, maybe slightly below average, retention. Just a slight bit of lacing left on one side.

S - Fairly acidic, vinegar smell along with some cherry tartness. Just a slight cherry sweetness. Hints of charred oak and a muskiness. That said, it is strongly acidic and tart.

T - Initially there is a strong acidic vinegary taste and a pretty strong tart/sour cherry taste. Fairly puckering taste. This gives way to a more funky and musty taste along with a hint of oaky/woody flavor. Then more fruity flavors come out in the middle to the end of the sip. Lots of cherry, still mostly tart/sour but a touch of sweetness, and hints of raspberry and grape like flavors. After drinking it for a while, the tart and acidic flavors go down a bit and the fruitiness comes out a bit more.

M - Medium body with about average carbonation. Fairly creamy and smooth but definitely has a drying and puckering finish to it.

D - Fairly good drinkability. A nice beer to sip on. Sour, tart, and acidic flavors quite prominent but there is a nice fruit taste and slight sweetness on the finish to balance that. Those make it so it is definitely a slow sipper, but an enjoyable one. Especially after it opens up a bit after drinking it for a while.

Notes: 2007 Kriek bottled 2009. Good sour beer from a brewery that knows a thing or two about sours. It was a little more acidic/tart and less fruit than I thought it may be, but thats not necessarily a bad thing. Really opened up after drinking it for a while, and the fruit started coming out a bit more. Enjoyable beer to sip, definitely recommend trying this.
Pours a very dark red with nice head. Aroma is cherries and some medicinal characteristics. Taste is mildly sour, oak and some funk. Pretty good but different.
Bottled 75cl. The color is remarkable- reminiscent of blood orange juice. A top notch kriek. Very sour and complex.

This was amazing. 2005 bottle. Dark burgundy red pour with minimal head. Simply beautiful. Huge cherry wine aroma with subtle oak, sourness, must. Huge tart cherry flavor with light oak backbone. Biting, puckering finish. Almost perfect for a lambic

Bottle via trade with Boutip, thanks! 2006 vintage. Pours a beautiful pinkish-red with a bit of pink foam. Aroma is very funky of course, but filled with cherries, yeast and wheaty notes as well. Taste is rather sweet for this style, lots of cherry juice and sourness. Palate is refreshing with a very dry finish, as per style. A good one.

(Bottle at Cantillon)
light cherry aroma, somewhat sweet, lots of yeast and spices and slight funk.
pours pink with rocky pink head.
flavor is again sweet-sour cherries, but bitter hops are marginally detectable.
its medium thin and dry. very nice overall, not too much cherry, but could be more sour.
On draft at TND.  Pours a clear fruit punch red with a medium sized light pink head.  Aroma of cherry cough syrup, fruit punch and light funk.  Taste is much the same as the aroma.

Bottle. Pours deep red, with flashes of pink and purple. Thick pink head, quite well-carbonated. Nose is bight cherries, with notes of cinnamon, nutmeg, a bit of the lambic sweatiness, nice Bretty tang. Flavors are exceedingly well-balanced and rich, lots of "Christmas cherries", solid earthiness, quite dry, which is always so nice in a Kriek, good lambic character beneath the cherry notes. A marvel of balance betweeen fruit and beer, the cherry notes are remarkable, while still showing off the inherent qualities of the lambic beneath.

Pours electric red no head light carbonation. Aroma of sour cherries. Flavour is very sour with a strong cherry flavour. It is almost like drinking a melted popsicle. Not bad. It is the most drinkable kriek I have ever had.

2003 Bottle - Thanks Buckeyeboy!! - Pours a hazy reddish purple with a small pink head...aroma is full of lemon and cherry, tannic wood, lactic buggies, more sour cherry...flavour is as expected, wonderfully fruity, the tannic fruit skins and acidity are tempered by the earthy wood...this was an awesome treat...

750 ml corked and capped bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. Vintage 2007, ABV is 5%. 300 gram of Schaerbeek cherries are added per liter beer. Aged in oak barrels. Deep red colour, huge pink head. Intense aroma of ripe cherries, hints of red wine vinegar. Equally intense flavour of sour cherries, not as lemony as the Lou Pepe Framboise. Drank it a bit too cold, still refreshing and pleasant to drink.
Crystal clear ruby red beer with a cherry and wood aroma. Light bitter, dry and sour taste. Very nice mild cherry taste. Dry tart finish. A very good kriek.

Vintage 2001, shared at RBWG 2010 by Ryan, I believe.  The pour is black cherry red and the aroma is sour cherries, Belgian yeast, and much more.  The flavor on this is amazing! An amazing blend of sourness and fresh cherry flavor mixed with the perfect blend of fresh cherry pie flavors, including crust, cinnamon, and more. This stuff is awesome!

Flaske årgang 2003: Flot dybrød klar øl med nogle enkelte bobler øverst der viser at karboneringen er som den skal være. Forholdsvis meget kirsebær i både duft og smag i betragtning af alderen på denne fremragende øl. Selvfølgelig er der den klassiske Cantillon surhed, men damn den drikker jo sig selv.

Had from bottle at Pizza Port Belgian Beer Festival - 2010 (2007 vintage).Poured a cherry color with slight fizzing and a little bit of lacing.  The head is mostly white with a bit of a red hue - it last all the way until the last drop.  The cherries and raspberries dominate the nose and also the flavors.  The nose is amazingly sweet while the beer itself is a bit on the sour side.  The alcohol is completely hidden within the beer which finishes with the slightest bit of acidity.  A must try.

A very nice lambic shared with Armando. Nice burgundy color in a hazy, dense body. In my opinion this lambics strength is its aroma with the blend of sour cherry, cinnamon and a bit of vanilla. It has a pleasant sourness, with no taste of alcohol. I really enjoyed it.

0,75 l bottle, Vintage 2007, shared with Balazs.
Poured hazy-murky claret-red, some floating snippet of fruits, pink froathy head that diminishes quickly to a minimal lacing one. Tart wooden cask aroma with sour cherries, vinegar and a moderated barnyard, some vanilla and vinous acidity. Strong, powerful character in the flavor too with a delicious tartness, like a craft wine, robust sourcherriy taste, bretannomyces yeasts. Dry, sourish and tart aftertaste. Atomically craft kriek lambic...
UPDATED: JUN 5, 2015 04 bottle. Dark ruby pour with tan head. Very acetic, huge sour flavor some vinegar and cherry. Bit better than non Lou pepe.

750mL bottle, 2006 vintage bottled 2008.   Pours a deep cloudy red, with a light pinkish head.  Smells absolutely incredible, like tart cherry pie.  Taste is tart, funky delicious cherries, with moderate acidity, fading into a bitter cherry peel finish.  Lots of oak.  The balance between tart, funky and bitter flavors is incredible.  The tartness is the most prominent.

2001 bottle shared by Ryan....huge thanks!  Pours hazy purple, thin white head.  Strong dark red wine and cherry aroma.  Tons of sour cherry, horse blanket, lemon and more metallic sour notes.  This is good stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2015   ( 2007 vintage) .  .   ...This kriek is down right  amazing, i mean this is  everything a fan of sour beers that happen to be  intertwined with fruit could  hope, pray or look  for . Its beautiful   purple/pink morphed colour -it looks like its bleeding cherry lacing on the glass and yes there is  a thin beer head making amazing pink island shapes  .     ..  !!!  .This aroma takes over my whole air space - a superb cherry funk pungent stench   . It is an aroma that is  blunt -it basically tells you this is a hardcore , intense -tart exercise  in lambic.   cherry stone tart bitterness clings to your palate and pintches it ...brett .blood.faint wheat accents showcase themselves in waves of a backdrop .  the ageing has made the sourness so so tart and kick ass. almost a perfect lambic-kriek .

Dark red pour with a fizzy head.  Aroma is bursting with tart raspberry seed and a bit of earth funk.   Mouthfeel is medium , tart, and dry.  Flavor is sour raspberry, a little bit of bitter raspberry seed, and some earthy funk.  Dry finish.  Great stuff

[2745-20100130] Bottle. Yeasty raspberry cherry toasted plastic aroma. Hazy, dark red body with a long-lasting foamy light pink head. Tart cherry sour raspberry flavour has bitter leaf yeast notes and a long sour aftertaste. Medium-full body is sour. Great combination of things coming together here. (Also, a fun huzzah for sharing in jercs 4000th rating! Yay!)
Overheard: "It looks like your confidence has been enhanced."
(c/o rudolf, w/ jerc, others)

2003 Bottle courtesy of BuckeyeBoy.  A reddish amber color with a creamy beige head.  Fruit filled nose with oak and cherries.  Sour and tart, here we come.  Dry cherry taste.  Oak.  Nice and tart.  Great fruit taste.  This was fantastic.

2005 Bottle, at Mess. Fabulous vivid dark red colour. Big fat juicy cherry aroma. Fruit of the highest quality has obviously been put to stunning use here. Lipsmacking flavour that has been engineered with all the requisite barnyard and sour qualities to near perfect levels of taste and finesse. Hands down the tastiest Kriek Ive thus far tasted. Big thanks to Mes for breaking this beauty open and furthering my lambic education.

750ml, 2006 vintage, dark reddish-wine color, with a small pinkyish head, nice musty, funky, bretty, barnyard, blackcherry sour nose, with a faint raspberry, rhubarb tartness, with a faint horseblanket, cow web aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a good tart, fruity cherry, faint raspberry, sour, acidic, iodic, light almondy pitted bitter character, with a funky, bretty, dusty, musty flavour and a hint of wildberry sourness and winey dry accent, leading towards a sour, cherry tart, acidic, dry finish.

2006.

Aroma is of course cherries, some other red pitfruit, yeast, hay, wet blanket, deep cloudy burgundy, pours a small very short lived pinkish head. Flavour is a cherry, almost lemon zing, barnyard as well. Light bodied, sour, tart, quite drinkable and very dry.   Lovely!

Draft at Teresas. 2007 Vintage. Pours pristine ruby red, almost like grenadine, with a thin, lacy white head. Aroma of sour fruit, with hints of cherry, strawberry, and peach. Body is thick and tart syrupy with a very bittersweet finish. Still cannont totally apprecite the lambic style.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2015 Draft at Teresas. 2007. It pours a bright red body with thin off white, pinkish head. Aroma is tart cherry and musky indoor pool, chlorine.  Mouthfeel is mouthpuckering tart palate with notes of extreme tart, sour cherries melting into pie crust. 2006 bottle care of Barry at franks. Pours a very deep cherry pour. Thin white lacing. Aroma is muted indoor swimming pool and cherries. Mouthfeel is sour and perfectly tart still at 8 years old. Incredible. Hitting full stride.

Nice pinkish color, nose has cherries and that barnyard funk i expect, flavor is tart and cleansing, the cherry is there but is muted by the sourness to a point. Great lambic should have aged it a while longer

1999 vintage, courtesy Cheeseman. Pours a cloudy ruby red color with a pinkish hue topped by a small, foamy pink head. The foam receds quickly leaving a thin film around the glass. The aroma shows some of that classis Cantillon barnyard funk, soured cherries, citric acidity, some musty yeast, and grapefruit. The tart cherries and their tannic skins are the main focus though. The flavor is quite sour and acidic with the soured cherries and citrus fruit up front, followed by the musty barnyard funk, old vinegar, and some wood. The old wood adds some nice earthy elements and some vanilla that smooth out the sourness. Medium bodied, puckering sour, with ample carbonation that leads to a sour cherry finish that keeps you coming back for more. This is an awesome lambic even with the 10 years, and could probably go for even longer. An awesome treat from Cantillon.

750 ml bottle, 2006 vintage. my bottle from a trade with boutip. shared with some bartowelers. pours deep burgudy with a pinkish soapy head. aroma of sour cherry pits, very big funk from the base lambic. quite different them the Lou Pepe we sampled just previous to this one. much more musty basement, and dusty barnyard. amazingly good and a very interesting when compared to the LP Frambroise.

The big round numbers are still fun, even if the numbers are not what its all about. Well not the only thing anyway. :) This year I have cheered on friends and fellow Torontonians who have passed the 4000th rating marker. Even better than the quest for ratings though,  are the people I have met along the way. The majority of my closest friends have known me since highschool and we maintain a pretty tight-knit group. Aside from sports teammates the majority of new friends I have made have been through Ratebeer and I think that that is pretty awesome.In 2009 I was lucky enough to marry Mabel who has become equally obssessed in the hunt for new beer ratings, and gleefully agreed to register for wedding presents at a gourmet beer store. In 2010 I am celebrating 4000 ratings with her, a bottle of Lou Pepe Pure Kriek (that we received as a wedding gift courtesy of a ratebeerian) and old friends  at Bacon Chocolate Fondue Party 2010. Huzzah!
2010-01-30. Very dark red body with a smallish pink head. Aroma of of non descript cherries with sour funky overtones. 7+ Flavour is quite sour as is the norm for Cantillon I suppose. Glimpses of cherries in the flavour are pleasant but fleeting as the sourness dominates. Average palate is lightly carbonated, which seems to suit the beer.  Well made, and bracingly refreshing. It is fitting perhaps that this bottle comes courtesy of rudolf who hosted a sour tasting a few years ago that finally got me to the point where I can drink and enjoy a nice sour beer. Still, this one is more intensely sour than my preference! A solid kick in the pants for my 4000th rating! 2005 Vintage bottle courtesy of rudolf, shared with Mabel and friends.
Great kriek with the right dusty blend of sweet and sour. The cherries are not too fierce and the taste is well rounded. Very dry. I had the 2003.

( 750ml bottle 2002 vintage thanks to BA mikeyv35) Pours opaque ruby with nice oily bubbles. Nose is funky, sour tart cherries, and vinegar. Smells insanely amazing. Taste of unsweetened cherries, cherry skin, perfectly sour body, oily, and mouth puckering finish. This beer was amazing.

(2006 vintage, bottled 2008)  No head. Slight ring of tiny bubbles along edge of glass. Cloudy cherry red body. Although its muted, a very nice aroma of cherries crossed with shoe leather and old running shoes. VERY tart flavors. Cherries are not really recognizable. Finishes with a flavor that I can best describe of what the leather ties on my old baseball glove used to taste like when Id pull on them with my teeth to tighten it up. Rather obscure, I admit, but its what comes to mind. Definately, not something Id want to drink on a regular basis, but sure is unique!!

2004 vintage via trade from bierkoning.  Thanks a lot, Edo!  This was epic.  I shared it at a tasting hosted by bulletrain76 on BA.  Pours a slightly hazy deep red color with a medium-sized white head and great lacing.  Aroma is intense tart cherries and barnyard funk.  You can feel the acid burning your nostrils, and its great.  Flavor is super-sour and acidic, but amazing.  Loads of tart cherries, cherry Jolly Ranchers, funk, and lacto/pedio/other wild bug tartness.  Brutal, but awesome.  Medium bodied with very high acidity and lively carbonation.  Drinkability is pretty good for a beer this sour.  Overall another great one from Cantillon.

Tap at the tiger. Poured a cloudy cherry red. Nose was sour and delicious. Not cheesy or stinky. Just solid sour. Nicely carbonated, acidic, very fruity, and very delicious. Even if you dont care for this style, its easy to drink. Very very good
Bevuta spillata al ma che siete venuti a fa il vintage del 2006... è sikuramente la migliore kriek ke abbia mai assaggiato... cantillon garanzia!!

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2014 Bottle courtesy thirdeye11.

2002 vintage drank in December 2009. Pours reddish brown with white head. Aroma is very sour, with wood, cherry, funk and vinegar all playing a part. Very complex and inviting. The flavor is very sour cherry with wood and barnyard funk also in there. This is one of the most tart beers I have had, but it is immensely drinkable. This is a beer I hope I get to try again.Notes from the 2007 vintage drank in August 2014 (the rating is still from the 2002 vintage). The beer was still very heavy on the cherries but there was also  a good bit of cinnamon and oak. Overall, the fruit has held up very well and the 2007 vintage is drinking superbly with 7 years go age on it.

2002 bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  red with a white head.  cherry skins, funk, wood and so much more.  wow incredibly smooth on the palate with flavors of cherries, sourness, wood and funk.  do want more

Bottle: Poured a deep cloudy red color lambic with a medium pink foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of naturally sweet and tart cherry is quite wonderful. Taste is also dominated by loads of lightly sweet and fresh cherries with some tart notes and a funky aftertaste. Acidity is very well balanced which is a bit surprising considering the base beer. World classic for sure and something I would drink more often is it was cheaper and more easily available.

Bottle courtesy of thirdeye11. Murky lipstick red appearance. Tart smell with some cherry fruit. Also has some sour vinegar. Taste is sour as anything Ive ever tasted. Wow. This flavor is all dominated by the level of sourness. Tart tart tart tart tart tart......

2007 bottle consumed in Nov 2009. 
Pour was midnight abortion red with a tight pink head. 
Nose is heavy cherry candy. 
Taste has a blend of tart and sweet cherry, nowhere near as sour as the regular kriek. Fairly disappointing because I was hoping for that cantillon pucker. Good if you want a fruit beer, bad if you want a cantillon.

2004 pour at Brouwers bigwood.  Incredible. Pours a beautiful fuchsia with a light rose head and lace.  A light sour aroma enhanced with cherries and candy sugar.  A sweet-tart of cherries.  Hard to describe the intense taste of this beer, but I am very glad it was available to sample.

Mind-blowing layers of awesome.  Aroma was floral and fruity.  Perfectly balanced Cherry, sour, earthiness and Belgium funkiness.  As it warms the funkiness gets a little overpowering so better colder.  There is a lot going on in this beer.  Honestly lost too much in the moment of drinking it to write proper notes.

Draft of vintage 04 at Brouwers Big Wood 09.  Poured red with a thin pink head.  Aroma is sweet and tart cherry.  The cherry is evident in the flavor but not dominant.  Exhibits a lot of funk and brett characteristics, earthiness, a sour punch, and a dry oak finish.   The barnyard funk became more pronounced as it warmed.  This is my favorite out of the lambics Ive had and one of my best beer experiences in general.  If only I could drink this all the time.

Bottle. Vintage 2003. Deep, hazy red-lilac color with a stylish pink head. Sour cherry aroma with a natural funky barnyard touch. The taste is sour, but not for being a Cantillon beer. Earthy, woody and vinous cherry taste. Big bodied and smooth.

2003 vintage bottle.
Pours blood red with a pink head. 
The cherries have meloved out into a complex and balanced beer.

Bottle from 2007 vintage.  Pours a reddish pink with a bright pink head that diminishes quickly.  Nose is not as tart as expected, tart cherry and slightly medicinal.  Flavor is slightly tart with a medium sweet finish, will re rate when I open my other bottle.

Cask at the GBBF:
An opaque red fuzz with a baby pink head.  Very interesting to look at.  True cherry, tart and mouthwatering.  A hint of sweetness is soon overwhelmed by the perfect level of acidity.  The flavour of the fruit is wonderful and accompanied well by the lightly woody finish.  The odd little carbonation leaves something to be desired but that is pretty much the only flaw.

2006 bottle thanks to Andy from Binnys for sharing! Pours a hazy cranberry sauce color with no head, maybe a few small white bubbles. Aroma is nicely sour and biting on the nostrils. Excellent farmhouse earthy notes along with a pleasing sweet and tart cherry. Flavor is immediately sour and tongue pinching, nicely acidic and funked out. Dry finish with some lingering tannins. Wonderful stuff

Bouteille verte de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Légère odeur de cerises acides et de couvertures pour cheval. Apparence: La couleur est rouge. Saveur: Goûte de cerises légèrement acide. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est mince avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Présence de cerises légèrement acide en arrière goût. (Rating #2766)

Sample #29 at 1st CST, 2005.  Pours a murky purple with a great white/pink froth.  Nice tart cherry pie aroma, pool water, great depth of cherries, lovely woody/cedar character, some spicy depth.  Flavor is of sour mold cherries, pool water, lots of funky tart cherries, very very sour yet mellowed for a Cantillon.  Med/full body with softer fluffy carbonation.  Love it... have another 05 bottle in the cellar.

Cask Stillage at the GBBF, Earls Court 05/08/2009
Sour fruit aroma. Blood red coloured sour fruity cherry flavour with a little dryness in a crisp lasting oaked finish.

Bottle, 1999 vintage, sampled 2009. Kindly shared by TheCheeseMan. Pours red with a faint ring of head. Nose is still donimated by cherry even after 10 years, hints of acidity, lots of funky barnyard and spicy brett. Flavor is more cherry, tart, acidic with some nice tannins. Dry and lush in the mouth. Drinkable with tart cherry and wonderful sourness throughout. Stunning.

04 bottle. Poured red. Flavor is a perfect blend of sour and sweet fruits and super tart funky, cheesy, lactic acid beer. The perfect amount of cherry and dry dry champagne like carbonation. This beer is phenominal. Musky wet cellar, funky dusty yeasts, mouthwatering pedio sourness.

I had the Lou Pepe 2005 Vintage. This poured a ruby red with a small white/off white head. The smell was excellent, it was fruity with a hint of vinegar. The taste was fruity and sour. I felt like the vinegar taste was not to strong. Overall this is a very good beer to have while relaxing.
draft (2007 vinatage): pours dark read with a creamy white head, cherry and tart aroma, dry, tart, citrus, cherry taste.  Excellent!
really strong flavor, extreme vinegar, so sour that it stings on the way down. Dont taste any cherries. tho. Bottle from Ryan Blanksis Sourfest- Hollywood, Florida.
Pours a ruby red with a small pinkish head.  aroma is tart with vinegar, wood and must.  Flavor is cherry with oak, and funk.  Cheek puckering tartness at the back end.  Very nice!
Reddish pour.  Aroma of sour cherries, wood, vinegar and earthy tones.  Flavor is sour as hell! Sour cherries, dry, earth, and did I mention sour?

Bottle. 2006 Vintage. Ruby beer with a pink head. Dusty/musty aroma with earthiness and cherries. Tart/sour cherry flavor with earthiness, must, and oak. Medium bodied. refreshing. Sour cherries and earthiness lingers. Good sour/fruit balance.
UPDATED: NOV 7, 2009 Savory aroma hinting to the strong sour flavor about to hit.  Extremely strong tart cherry flavor.  This is the finest sour beer Ive ever had!

2006 bottle. This rosy purple lambic ale poured with no head at all and a fragrant cherry aroma. There is a delicious schaerbeekse cherry flavor that is much more mellow than the average sour cherry. There is an incredible tart finish. Mmm good. Craig (City Beer), thanks for finding this beer for me.

Thanks to marcus for sharing this rarity. This is the 2006 vintage. Pours darkly cherry. No head. Delightful sour cherry aroma. Medium body. Mild carbonation. Flavor is smooth, moderately sour cooking cherry. Delightfully sour. Mellow. Truly a great beer.

750ml, 2003 vintage, with a huge thanks to kujo9 for one of the best bonus beers Ive ever gotten!  Pours a hazy bright pinkish red with a good sized pinkish white head.  Aroma is musty, lightly funky and earthy, and tart cherries.  Flavor has a nice pucker factor without going overboard, along with more tart cherry, funk, earth and mustiness.  Nice, nice stuff, a huge thanks again Mike!
deep Burgandy red ... big fruity cherry nose ... sweet sweet fruit ... lots of cherry ... low sourness ... refreshing.

Dark purple body leaves no lacing, a brief creamy pink head.  Aroma is tart cherry, sweet sugary with a slight earthy dusty funk.  Flavor has strong fruity tartness, a dry puckering sour, cherry, and deliciousness.  Palate is a strong dry sour.  Awesome.

BPW #10
Sampled from 750 mL bottle of the 2004 vintage (bottled in 2006) courtesy of Andy. This elixir poured a strawberry red tone with some nice retreating bubbles. Nose is full of Brett funk, barnyard, and some barrel notes. Flavors follow the nose closely with the barnyard intensity growing every sip and puckering the mouth. The mouth is well carbonated and becomes chalky at times. A real nice brew, although it wrecked havoc on my stomach in the morning.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2014 Have had this a few times over the years but this rating is for a particular 2003. bottle shared by JB I think, thanks.  So this was bottled in 2005 and thus 4 years old in the bottle. Pours a beautiful deep ruby red color, small and bubbly but long lasting head.  Thick beer, cannot see through it.  This Lou Pepe is very different from most of the Cantillon lineup.  Its just not so "Cantillon" with the crazy sourness and lemony bretty.  Instead there is a spicy cherry with a cherry pie crust thickness.  And of course lambic cobwebs are abound on the nose.  Its is nice to have these two characters in harmony.  The cherry is a lot more tart in the flavor.  This allows the barnyard and cobweb characteristics to really shine as well.  All this sits on your palate for a long time.  I mean I feel like it would sit around for an hour.750mL, Duvel tasting glass. 9/4/9/4/17 = 4.3 <BR
2011 bottle as part of a blind tasting, so it was also about 4 years old. Overall I gave it a 3.7.  New score is the average of the two.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Dans Bachelor Party Extended Weekend Rating #9 of 90. Brewed 2004, bottled 2006, shared with Dan and friends. Pours into wine glass a brownish red. Strong sour funk leaps from the glass along with some red fruits (honorable mention to JT and Nolan for saying this smells like cat food...do you smell it?). From the first sip to the last this has a sharp sour bite, funk, and piercing bite on the tongue. Either you dig it or you dont...I dig it! Leaves your mouth wanting more.

2003 750 ml bottle I bought a couple years ago from Plaza Liquors - Pours a hazy reddish-brown color with a 3/4 finger thick light pink head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is tart esters.  Flavor is tart cherries and lemon.  The sourness really lingers.  Medium body.  A decent beer.  Just wish I didnt have to drink the whole bottle myself.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2010 06 bottle pours very minor pink ring for a head atop an unbelievable ruby color, just bursting and vibrant to the eye. Loads of leather and hay along with strong cherry, confirms the unbelievable eye. It would actually benefit from turning the brett down a notch as it ends up imparting a latex note. Tart flavor, singularly driven from on high with cherry so deep that you can dive into it. Odd finish, rather watery but also with hints of lactic lemon that linger. Love the cherry. The rest is hit or miss. 07 bottle against a hoard of Krieks, wins out against all of them. dark translucent red, large rocky pink head. Nose very cherry, light cobwebs and must, very sweet overall though. Lots of balance in sour flavor, still cherry, dusty, moldy, and bit sweet and earthy through finish. Easily best so far, fruit integrated and balanced. Nose a bit sweet, finish flat an watery at room temp. 859418

Few vintages sampled. I seem to like them all. Lots of nice cherry and sour funk. Tons of acidity and very puckering. Prickly on the tongue and really quite sour. A little wood and sour cherry finish this one. Fun.

75cl bottle shared by bret27.   The best of the night for rating 1300.   This was a beast of a beer.   I loved their regular kriek when I had it, but this just takes it to another level of sour-cherry-amazingness.   Opaque red in color with a small head.   Awesomely funky sour lambic nose with lots of tart cherries.   There is a lot of cherry on the flavor as well, but very dry and sour in the mix.   Very lactic and citric in the tartness, but very rounded into the cherry.   Light and spritzy mouthfeel.   I need to get the rest of the Lou Pepe lineup now...

Bottle courtesy bret27. Poured into a Bruery tulip. Deep strawberry red with a light pink head that fades quickly due to the expected acidity. Aroma is lemons and sour cherries, a hint of sweet strawberry, oodles of citric acid. Flavor is very sour but with a solid amount of fruitiness to balance. Sour cherries, slight musty earthiness, old wood, straw. Pretty great kriek.

05 vintage Bottle thanks to Gerrit at the First Annual Chicago Sour Tasting.  Hazed red purple color with a thin off white head.  Tart cherries, dark fruits, interesting nose.  Dark fruits, cherries, lots of cherry juice thats tart, acidic and tasty.  Solid.
From 2006 vintage bottle.  Dark cloudy red, aroma is sour and a little funky, sharp acidic tart cherry, long sour finish.

Ruby red in color with a decent sized pink head. Aroma is sour, cherry, funk, hay, raspberry, light earth. Taste is of sour cherries, with a tart finish thatblends into a pastry-likr aftertaste. Light wood in flavor and very dry.
2006 bottle.  Reddish pour, vinegar, cherries, funk, feet, oak.  Tiny and minimal carbonation.  Pithy and tart.  Quite good.
Beautiful deep pinkish orange pour with little pink bubbles on top. Beautiful beer. Cherries and citrus in the nose and flavor. Lively palate. Decent oak finish.
Sampled at the 2009 Stone Sour Festival. Outstanding! I know I had this before but missed the rating. Tart cherries with a touch of lemon peel. Very good.

2005 vintage thanks to Gerrit, tasted during the First Annual Chicago Sour Tasting.  Cloudy red with pancake pink head.  Aroma is off-dry raspberry, funk, slight sour.  Flavor is sour, great fruit component, that cherry quality is really nice, tart.  Medium to light body with active carbonatin.  Fantastic, really fruity, love it.

Bottle, thanks to Jimbowood.  Deep red pour with light pink head.  Aroma is leather, effervescence, tart cherries, lemony.  Flavor is the same, very tart and lemony, not that much funk in the flavor, and there is some wet wood flavor as well.

750ml bottle at Saint Bock. Front label said Kriek 2005. Back label said bottled August 2007. Pours red with small head. Retention is short but a small ring stays there until the end. Aroma is really sour and hints of cherries. Taste is also very sour with hints of cherries. Finish is long sourness. I have a hard time describing it. From my description, it may seems simple but the sourness makes it very complex and enjoyable until the end ! My fourth lambic/gueuze. Im still learning to appreciate them !

Bottle from Zinister at the Houston sour tasting.  Thanks, man!  Pours a solid cherry red (tampon red) with an aroma of curry-infused body odor.  Flavor is lingering sour cherry candy perfume.  Average mouthfeel.  A very lingering and complex sour.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: The look is very red. Go Big Red! Nice pink head, looks inviting.  The smell is cherry, very nice, fruits, tart, good funk complexity, and sour. The taste is fruits, cherry, sour, very refreshing, wood, tartness.  Very dry. Awesome beer.
On tap at Brouwers Sour Fest.  Pours cloudy dark magenta with minimal head.  Amazing cherry pie aroma- sweet and tart.  Tastes like it smells and finishes sour.

Pours beautiful crimson / ruby red with a very small pinkish head.  The aroma is rich and tart cherries, citric sourness, wild yeast, pepper, dark berries and some pith-like notes.  It is sour, but very smooth as well.  Medium / thin body thats quite grainy with very soft carbonation - far too easy drinking of a beer.  The flavor starts nice with a more assertive sourness that the aroma.  There is dry cherry, quite a bit of wood, wild yeast and a lemon/lime citric bite.  The finish is clean and refreshing with a sour, puckering pleasant bite.  An excellent lambic.

Tap at Brouwers post sour fest. Pours an awesome bright red with a fantastic pinkish red head. The aroma is all cherry, sour sweet. Smells very nice. Initial tart kick is followed by medium sour cherry flavors and a lingering tart finish. Love the sweet/sour aspect in the nose and less so in the flavor. The natural cherry flavors are fantastic, the tart finish pulls it all together. This was almost amazing to me... a really fine, fine beer. The only complaint I would have with this one is that it is not over 10% nor was it a pale strong....

Tap @ Spuyten Duyvil.  Pours a ruby red with a small pinkish head.  Aroma is sour cherry and that Belgian funk that we love so much.  Taste is the same, with the flavors taken to a completely new level.  I got sour cherry, I got nuts, I got earthy notes, and a wonderful cherry/brett tart finish.  Its fantastic.

Draft at Brouwers Cafes Sourfest. Unfairly, this rate applies only to the draft version. When I can scrape the $40 together, Ill rate the bottle. Heh. :-)Gorgeous, gorgeous dark red opaque body. Still. Headless. Laceless. Lovely sweet and sour cherry nose, just not much else there. Still, watery body. Lots of sour cherry and maybe a bit of mineral bite on the mid-palate. And thats about it. Tart finish. One-dimensional, alas.

On draft at Brouwers sour ale fest. Pours a dark pink - an almost fluorescent color, with no head - just a ring of tiny bubbles. Cherries, wood, port wine and some sugar. The aroma is incredibly tart - like a cherry jolly rancher - though the flavor was a bit smoother. Just a bit of dusty yeast as well. Great to be able to try this one on draft. Probably the best kriek Ive had, but it was a little intense for me.

Bottle that I picked up either at brewery last July orDranken Geers in March, cant remember where, consumed 13-05-09   Poured a most wonderful rich red bloody colour, bit like opening a vein and pouring it in your glass, but that would be less likely to have a fluffy pink head. Instant sour cherries on the nose and dusty old mantelpiece, it also exudes funk. Really tart, cherries are all over your mouth like a rash, invading every nook and cranny and zipping about like you wouldnt believe, this is so cherry that other than some sour woodiness I really struggle to pick up much else. Its great, refreshing the perfect summer drink, tart, funky cherries and it really is  all about the cherries, cherrytastic, not arf mate.  A8 A5 F8 P4 Ov16  4.1

2004 bomber, shared with three buddies.  Pours opaque brownish-pink with a light pink head and soapy bubbles.  Aroma is of sour cherry, acidity, and vinegar.  Flavor builds slowly, starting with sour cherry (sirenam?), maybe some pear and lemon as well.  Middle flavors move towards sharper sour cherry and general acidity.  Finishes with a cranberry-like tart bitterness.  Palate remains soft throughout, though it gains a coating quality in the acidic finish of this beer.  Overall, I enjoyed drinking this one, but it lacked wow quality.  Another concern:  Im not sure that this bottle was optimally stored, since it has been in an environment that has temperature fluctuations between 65-75 degrees.

On tap at Novare Res.
Pours a pinkish red color with a very light pinkish head.  Aroma is sour cherries, funky, and straw like.  Flavors are cherries, barnyard, leather.  Very tart, but dry too so its not painful.  Its a cherry champagne and its delicious!

On tap at the Hopleaf. Truly wonderful beer. Pale pink-red color; a blushing maiden if you will! Awesome aroma: vinous, strong sour cherries, some leather, hay. Flavor was like eating a sour cherry pie w/ some crisp mountain water thrown in. Tart, long lingering sour cherry aftertaste. Thin body ending clean and dry. Superb stuff as usual from the folks at Cantillon. Lip-smackingly good; sour and tart w/ restrained acidity.

Tap at Spuyten Duyvil: Beautiful murky deep blood red with a pink bubbly ring of head. Outstanding aroma! Classic Cantillon funk- lots of lactic acid, sharp leathery wild fermentation character, rustic/farmhouse, mold, very soft oak tannins, tart cherry skins and a subtle underlying almondy sweetness. Slick and acidic body. Complex and sour. Lots of lactic, pedio, rustic, infectious, notes as well as oak character- tannins, subtle vanilla underneath all the funk. The sour cherry notes are there meshing with the overall leathery wild fermentation flavors, with a touch of almond from the cherry. An exceptional Fruit-Lambic!

On tap at Spuyten Duyvil at their Cantillon & de la Senne event.  Pours a deep garnet/ruby color without any head to speak of, just a couple of soda sized bubbles around the edge of the glass.  Smells like cherry pie filling with a touch of acid.  Nice clean cooked cherry aromas.  Thin bodied, but the flavor follows the nose and is absolutely delicious, a nice sour cherry flavor.  Finishes with more cherry flavor and a light citric acid.  Delicious.

My thanks to ajm for cracking this one open, despite the comments that follow.  Pours an interesting pomegranate color with a foamy pink head.  Smells absolutely terrible.  My God.  I cant believe I drank this beer knowing how bad it smells.  Tastes of ruby red grapefruit juice and underripe strawberries.  Sours on the finish with an added note of dry wood.  Pepe Le Pew.

2004 Bottle, 2006 cork courtesy of SoLans guess my dinner contest.  Thanks Alan!  Nose, while very foot-filled, is not deeply funky as much as tart.  The whole opening was very acerbic for everyone in nose and flav.  Once that goes away, waves of strawberry, tart cherry, green apple and vinegar are evident in the taste.  This continues endlessly, making this a beer your mouth cannot get used to.  Color is a nice deep but bright red with no lasting head.  Solid ticket to get me into the 700 Club.

2002 vintage.  Pours a hazy ruby red grapefruit color with a small, foamy, light pink head.  A glassy surface emerges in the center as the foam recedes, while scant, wet spots of lace mark the glass randomly.  The nose shows a classic Cantillon profile, dusty horseblanket funk overtones alongside dry, citric acidity, tannic cherry skins, and musty, wet cave stones.  Grapefruit and apricot are fully detectable, even though cherry is the primary focus.  In short, it smells fantastic.  As expected, the flavor is strikingly sour and acidic, notes of aged Balasmic vinegar joining the tart kriek and citrus fruit, with more musty horseblanket and earthy, mineral components.  Soured, saturated wood, impart a soft, oaky vanilla taste that pairs well with the cherry.  Dry, almost parching, puckering, and tingly on the tongue and the back of the throat, each sip begs the next.  Like most things Cantillon, this is a standout.  Great stuff.

750mL bottle 2001 vintage poured into a tulip.

Pours a hazy cherry red with brown hints and a big fluffy pink head that stays on as a cap for the duration.

The aroma is initially funky but as it warms the cherries come out a little bit more, more tart than sweet, but definitely there.  There is a bit of sugary sweetness in there as well but the funk and acidic vinegar is pretty strong.

The taste has the same acidic funkiness as the aroma with a combined tartness from the cherries up front that puckers the lips from the outset.  After the initial kick, the sugary sweetness of the cherries makes an appearance along with a bit of brown sugar.  But the finish brings back the sourness and funk.

The mouthfeel is dry and puckering with good carbonation and medium bodied.

Once again, Cantillon has produced a beer that I enjoy but has really kicked up the vinegar sourness to point that it takes over the cherry presence.  Still, very good.
firtst lambic evr tried.shocked by the raspberry colour and aroma.enjoyed very much the raspberry and strawberry tastes and the fantastic notes of red wine,medium body,provides a lot of acidity
woah, very sour and shocking.."i cant open my left eye"-after the first sip... rasperberry  colour, low head ring .. . very bold, with a touch of musk, pretty strong stuff .. .my stomach hurts.. .

Bottle shared with NickTheElder at Boho.  Poured a hazy dark ruby color with no head.  Aroma is lots of cherries, clean and fruity, barrel starts coming out as it warms with a nice funk and some vanilla.  Flavor is very tart and delicious!  Barely any sweetness but lots of fruity notes with a dry red wine like finish.  Prickly on the palate and medium bodied.  Way too easy to drink!

[Vintage 2004] Bottle...  Poured a cloudy red with a light, pink head.  Not much of an aroma.  Insanely dry and tart with a nice sizzle on the tongue.  Light fruit flavors but nothing identifiable as probably a result of the five year age.  The dry finish was a bit scratchy.

Botella. Deep beautiful red colour. Sour cherry fruity wood aroma. Great mouthfeel. The flavour is sour with lots of fruitu cherries, light bitterness, some wood and a dry fruity long lasting finish. Yum indeed!

March Houston Tasting. Thanks to pantanap I think. Pours a bright red with pink head. Nose of cherry pie and soft sour notes. Flavor is pretty much light cherries...easy to drink...subdued. Straight-forward, easy to drink Lambic.
bottle thanks to zinister.  vintage 2005.  Pours a bright burgundy with a pink head.  Nose is powerful abundance of cherries.  Taste is sour cherries.  Mouthfeel is tart and puckery.  Very nice.

Bottle kindly shared by faroeviking. Thanks chief. Its a beauty. Cloudy red body with a big steady pink head. Loads of sour cherries and wood in aroma. Very fruity flavour with lots of cherries. Its sour and dry. Crispy and tart body. Really good stuff.

Bottle shared by faroeviking. 
Pours hazy red with a dense medium pink head. 
Aroma is dry with notes of acidic cherries. 
Flavor is very dry with notes of cherries and grape. Uhmm delicious!

2005 bottle thanks to Zinister at the Houston RB funk/gueze/lambic/sour tasting. Pours blood red-beautiful-with a small thick head. Nose is very fruity, tart, cherrys. Taste comes off tangy, tart, cherries present, in the background and not overwhelming. Well balanced, huge mouth, and very drinkable. Great beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text:
UPDATED: MAY 2, 2012 2008 version. clear dark red, large smooth pink head that soon disappears.
Aroma is lambic, lots of sweet cherries, woody note, dryish even with the sweetness.
flavor: very refreshing and citrussy, brett and lovely fruity tones to build the balanced flavor. cherries are there, but perfectly balanced. Quenching, very good stuff.
.2008 version bottled 2010. from plan-b.clear red, quite large pink head that disappears REALLY fast. 3 aroma of marcipan, cherries, funk, leather, tart and sour notes. 7. flavor is near perfect for a sour fruit beer, lots of sour lambic, rounded off by sour cherries, appears extremely fresh and quenching, with enough detail and complexity to be very interesting. 9 pal 4 ov 18. same rate.
2001 version kindly shared by ungstrup at his place.Lets just say that the 2001 is going strong and tastes superior. i gave it 9,3,9,3,19 but I was pretty wasted at that time. Thanks a bunch jens for sharing.
(Big bottle from Pelgrims, 2005 label) Dark red with tiny head. Smells like "fricandon with kriekskes". Very deep kriek-flavor. Exceptional kriek.

1999 on the label. poured had this last year. poured a cloudy reddish color with a small off white head with some pink in it. aroma sour cherries,  some barn yard in a good way, earthy . Flavor same as aroma. Very easy to drink I liked this beer will try to gey more

Green bottle, 2005, 75 cl, bottled on August 2007, best before 12/2015, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured on March 22 2009; eye: burgundy, lightly hazy, no effervescence, pink head that disappears completely, no lacing; nose: cherry, sugar, Brettanomyces yeast, horse; mouth: cherry, residual sugar, acidity, sourness, Brettanomyces yeast, horse, finale in cherry with a good presence of yeast and acidity, medium body, rather carbonated, mildly sweet and acidic, rather sour, slick; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille verte, 2005, 75 cl, embouteille le 22 août 2007, meilleure avant 12/2015, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savourée le 22 mars 2009; il : bourgogne, légèrement voilée, pas deffervescence, mousse rose qui disparaît complètement, pas de dentelle; nez : cerise, sucre, levure Brettanomyces, cheval; bouche : cerise, sucre résiduel, acidité, aigreur, levure Brettanomyces, cheval, finale en cerise avec une bonne présence de levure et dacidité, corps moyen, plutôt carbonatée, moyennement sucrée et acide, plutôt aigre, coulante; en résumé : bien

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2010 On tap at the Maproom, Chicago on 12-27-08. Burgundy/pink color with a pinkish head. Very horsey aroma, with little hints of sourness. But the flavor is extremely sour, vinegar-like, with cherries in the background. One of the most interesting beers Ive ever had.

2002 Vintage enjoyed in 2009. 750ml bottle.  Pours a hazy red/pink body with a whispy pink head.  Aroma is sour lactic acid, very acidic, with hints of woodiness.  Big sour funky cherries, very dry and acrid and sour funk.  Dry and mouthwatering.  Very delicious, made some awesome blends with the last 1/4 of the bottle.

Wow!!!! I love this beer. 
Sour flavor all the way through, just the way I like it!
Great looking beer too - purplish red hue with no head.
Looking for this one again? yes

2006 Vintage. Tasted like it needed some more time. Pours with just a thin foam of head. Vibrantly, beautiful red body. Very pretty. Strong  cherry aroma with oak tannins and an ever so light funk. Taste is somewhat sour and very dry with wood and cherries. Not nearly as sour as I was expecting. Very light carbonation, slightly puckering mouthfeel. Wasnt sour enough, feels like it is missing something. I greatly preferred the Lou Pepe Framboise.

Brewed 2005/Bottled 2007. a deep red beer with a quickly dissapearing pink head. The aroma has a bit of must with light wisps of tart cherries. The flavor starts tart and acidic, gets a little bit sweeter, almost like cherry pie filling, and finishes with dry wood and more tart fruit. Really good.

Bottled sample, 2001 vintage via Rudge75. Deep ruby in colour with moderate carbonation. Very funky on the nose, with notes of barnyard, earth, faint sweet cherry, and latex paint. Mellow and light bodied in the mouth with more cherry (pits and all), lemon rind, and wood. It strikes a nice balance between lactic and citric sourness. Perhaps my least favorite of the Cantillon Lou Pepe series, but still fine stuff.

$24 750ml bottle neck reads 2005 and the cork and back label are marked 2007. Wonderful pink color with a head that looks amazing for all the three seconds it lasts upon being poured. Smells only slightly farm-like. Tastes like tart cherry lambic, delicious. Not nearly as acidic as the regular Cantillon kriek and is much easier to drink.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-15-2009 02:54:11

2004 bottle. Dark ruby hue with spritzy pink head that gradually dissipates. Aroma of cherry pie, berries, pie crust, acetic sourness, and funk. Flavor is sour cherries and berries, some wood and vanilla tones, finishes with slight mouth-puckering sweet tart sensation. Medium-bodied, watery smooth texture, and lively carbonation. A nice fruity sour ale with lively mouthfeel, the sourness  dissipates leaving a pleasant cherry syrup aftertaste.
2003 bottle. Pours a hazy red with a pink head. Acidic flavour of berries and wood. Finish is lightly sweet, heavily acidic. Will probably not buy another bottle.

22oz 2004 bottle at the SATRG. Pours a reddish cherry color, very cool poor with a small pinkish red head. The nose is just crazy with hints of cherry, alot of vineagar but not as much as I expected. Also some vanilla, alot actually and some funky brett. WOW this thing is motherpuckering in a good way. Very complex, cherry skins, acidic with some strong funky cheese notes and a vanilla end with a pure cherry jam finish. This is a heck of an amazing beer.
Crushed with Jakeba and co.  Not the best nose.  But the flavor is just about as much as you want.  Sour strawberries and awesomeness.  Not quite worth the price, but definitely sexy.

Bottled at Horsens Beerfestival. Deep red body with a small pink head. Nice aroma of cherry, acid and barnyard. Flavor is refreshing sour, cherry, a hint of almond and wood. Very nice indeed and less sour than many other beers from Cantillon.

Tasted 2008-12-30. Bottle from 2005. Pours dark purple/red - almost black. Quickly dissappearing head. Smells sour, rough. Barnyardish. Some hidden sweet cherries in there. Very acidic and yet somewhat bitter taste. Very wild. Quite tasty.

On Tap @ Maproom. Pale pinky red color with a minimal  head. Great aroma and taset of wonderful sour cherries. A little bit of lambic funkiness to go along with it. The flavor is somewhat watery but fantastic none-the-less. A bit too easy to drink for the price.
Purple haze.  Aroma of sour cherries being chewed by horses.  Sour at the back of the palate, with fruit up front.  Musty dry finish.  Clasic

2006 on draft at Map Room. Pours a nice, purpley pink red. Nose is quite subdued, relatively. Nice oak notes with old grass and hay, cherry fruit roll-ups and a little funk. Taste is much the same. very subdued acidity for a Cantillon. Mellow and tart with a definite cherry taste. Finish is nice and long with oak notes and more cherry coming through. Much preferred to Schaerbeekse, actually. Very nice.

Pours a ruby red with a thin pink head. Aroma of sour cherries, wood and barnyard funk. Flavor is complex and tart with sour cherries, wood/oak, funk, acidic and nicely carbonated. Light to medium body with a tart dry finish. Excellent lambic.

Sampled during Minnesota first annual Sourfest and shared by Badgerben. Pours a semi-hazy mahogany brew with a fizzy pinkish head that slowly dissipates to an off-white ring. Aroma of tart cherries, barnyard funk, some sour dough bread and light citrus. Taste is spritzy, medium bodied with flavors of yeast, cherries, a touch of vanilla and oak. Finish is semi-tart, dry with a metallic cherry aftertaste. Pretty much a solid Kriek.
Bottle w/ Maheu awhile back.  A juicy, cherry filled tart brew.  I recall it being a tad thin.  But a balls out, tasty kriek.  Cherry is the name of the game..

On draft at Zeno’s, Penn State.  Poured beautiful deep red with lively pink head.  Lots of sour cherries in the nose.  Extremely tart, more so than I was expecting.  Tartness and acidity mask a bit of the cherry flavor.  Slightly disappointing.

Pours milky ruby red with thin pink rose head. Cherry and balsamic vinegar are prevailent in the nose, with lots of oak musty fall time prairie grass, rye bread and green walnut skin. Flavor is a revelation for me, I have had lambics before but nothing quite like this, tingly sour cherry skins so acidic it burns a little not quite a vinegar taste to it but definitely acidic. There are some funk notes in there but very pleasant and interesting, like the smell of a wet maple tree. Other notes I picked up were oak, vanilla, wheat, lime, grapefruit, mullberries that aren’t quite ready yet, and potatoe skin. Body is thin dry and so acidic it is impossible to detect alcohol content. With all of this talk of high acidity I think many people could be scared off by these reviews, but its really far less vinegar like than most wines, its almost more of a citric acid tingle. Very interesting, and very good.

2002 bottle.  Poured deep, perfect deep garnet with a well-retained pinkish-eggshell head.  The aroma was so tart it almost tinged my nose hairs.. sour cherry skins led with funky, abrasive, almost metallic sour vinegary notes in there too.. very rich.  The flavor opened by burning the tip of the tongue with a bracing cherry vinegar impression.. more cherry skins and tart wheat rock the middle, with more vinegary notes finishing (which burns all the way to the stomach).. excellent stuff!  Rough on the palate, but I really enjoyed it.. I havent had a beer this sharp in a while.
A beatiful red color with faint head.  Cherry and sour barnyard funk on the aroma, but a little light.  The body was likewise very sour with a faint hint of cherry.

Deep, dark, lovely looking kriek with a superb, complex aroma of oak, candy, cherries, concentrated and funky. Smooth bodied, lively with allot of taste, very oaky and complex. Full of taste, kind sourness but still enough. Dry oaky aftertaste. A really lovely kriek, best one I have tried yet.

Sours, real Belgian sours are a love/hate relationship. As a beer drinker, you either love them or hate them. Some start out hating them and then come to love them, but some just never develop that palate or almost fanatical love for real mouth-puckering Belgian sours. Once you go sour, you never go back, and like euphoria, it draws you ever deeper into her fold and I am happier and more blessed for it.

Cantillon Lou Pepe Pure Kriek is a bottle of delicious pinkish mouth-puckering and watering sour Belgian delight. I can’t think of any better way to describe, and as I write my review, I find myself wishing I had a glass or two to enjoy while I do so.

She pours a cloudy-white punch red with some nice powdery sediment in the finish. Her nose is aglow with sour cherry and raspberry notes. I imagine fields of under-ripe green cherries and raspberries being plucked and crushed right before my eyes as the aroma overwhelms my senses. My first quaff is a sour one-two punch reminding me of the sugar-free lollipops the dentist used to give out which I abhorred, and yet as an aspect of Cantillon’s Lou Pepe Pure Kriek I can’t imagine a more perfect flavor. Not to be outdone, hints of sweet concentrated sugar and sour-unripe berries march right alongside. Her body is light and lingers with but a wee bit of a dry finish as my tastebuds immediately water and demand another quaff. I happily oblige of course, and some sour pink grapefruit notes join the unripe cherries and dark berries to further delight all of my senses. As I finish my Cantillon Lou Pepe Pure Kriek, I can’t help but feel a tinge of sorrow, knowing that our time together is almost over, but I shall always remember her with a twinkle in my eye and an empty glass ready for another filling.

I don’t get to enjoy too many real sour Belgians, whether they are Krieks or Lambics or any of the other fruit flavored sour varieties, but of the ones I have had so far, hands down the Lou Pepe Pure Kriek from Cantillon is my personal favorite. While her thrown may get ousted one day, she shall never travel far from my favor.
Vintage 2003. Red with a big pink head, fat like whipped cream. Beautiful. Nice woody aroma of cherry. The flavour is sour, tart and acid but much more balanced than many other brews from Cantillon.
Pours out a hazy red. Smell is lightly fruity. Taste is tart and funky. With nice woody notes. Somewhat sweet. Not as sour as the regular kriek. Great complex lambic. Very tasty.

1999 corked and capped bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville (their last bottle... hurrah!) Pours a hazy red with a thin, creamy off-white head. Aroma of sour cherry, wood, horseblanket, funk, sweet hay. Somewhat earthy. Taste is sour cherry with wood and barnyard notes, and an herbal note reminiscent of celery. Very tart. Full bodied.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2015 A beautiful red color and a great beer, but it was beat by the lp framboise in a side by side. Mild cherry aroma with lambic aroma.  Sour cherry in the aroma and flavor, but not as sour as the raspberry.  Still an exceptional product, and it is quite sour.7/5/8/5/16 UPDATE: 2004 vintage, purchased at the brewery in 2006. I liked it more this time. Characteristic Cantillon sour yeast, in both the aroma and flavor. A surprising amount of cherry in the aroma and the flavor, for an 8 year old lambic.  Some cinnamon as well, which I understand is from the cherry pits.

2001 Vintage.  Tasted September 7, 2008.  Dark red color with a thin head.  Light cherry aroma.  The taste was packed with a great blend of fresh and dried cherries.  Lightly tart.  Missing the sourness of a lot of Lambics.
Ottimo! La ciliegia si abbina molto bene con il gusto acido caratteristico del lambic.

Carolina Crew tasting.  Bottle courtesy of Todd and Bob?!  Thanks!  99 & 04 vintage. Muddy red pour.  Acidic, funky, cherry .  The 99 was an excellent beer with lots of barnyard, oak, leather, and cherry. 
Cherry flavors were more evident in the 04

Bottle; ’99 and ’04 tried side by side.  ’99 was more muddy, pink with brown/orange tints to it.  ’04 was brighter dark pink.  Both were phenomenal, though the ’99 blew me away.  More acidic and gueuzy, sour, lemony, and earthy in addition to the cherry notes.  The cherry was not at all overpowering in the ’99.  Acted more as one of many flavors instead of being dominant.  ’04 had a bit of diaper smell upon opening, but had more cherry (pits and skins included) than the ’99.  Great lambic--worth the price.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2010 pours a dark gumwood with minimal head. Aroma of cherry, bread and biscuit, and some vinegar. Flavor is complex- tart and yeasty at the start with hints of barnyard, and smooths out to a sweeter cherry hint at the end. Lots of vinegar. Palate is powerful. Not my style, but i can certainly appreciate such an interesting and complex beer. Very nice. 

Rerate- boy, was I a rookie when I first had this brew. Just had an 05 vintage courtesy of Chris from Ebenezers. That year of the Lou Pepe has got to be one of the best krieks out there. Absolutely amazing.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2012 Vintage 05. Pours ruby brown with minimal head. Aroma is riddled with cherry aromas with some funk and tartness. Quite sour. Flavor is powerful with tarness welcomed but not overpowering. Cherry pucker with funk and barnyard. Acidic but not overly so, with yeast character welcomed. Palate is slightly of vinegar, lively carbonation and tart, palate smacking. Incredible.


Rerate: Had a 2005 bottle- there has to be something about this vintage- incredible.   


2008 is even better...

05 Bottle shared by Crosling, thanks dude.  Poured a beautiful, deep ruby red color with a thin berry red head that diminished quickly.  Aroma of sour cherry, acidic vinegar, and some funky yeast.  Tart, funky entry leads into a sour cherry middle with some light vinegar, ending with some moderate yeastiness and undertones of soft berry.  Acidic bite and light carbonation.  Pretty good beer.

Vintage 2005. Pours reddish pink with pink head. Aromas of cherries and sour funk. Flavor is tart cherries that puckers my mouth. Light to medium body with lively carbonation and a dry finish. Excellent!

Vintage 2005; bottled 2005.  A bloody red pour, thick and silty, with a frothy pink foam making it seem lighthearted, if only for a moment.  Stable and cheese aroma with a fat cherry skin sweetness.  A hint of brown sugar and a brazen dry wood tannin presence to balance the funk, briefly; but, the musty cave and farm aromas tend to outlast the characters of the malts and fruit, in minerals, gouda rind, a funky blend of mildew and cinnamon, and rotten fruit.  The sharpness and foulness it shows is arresting, but it seems a little young yet; many of the older Cantillons in my memory are notably more settled in the nose, allowing the nuances ample spotlight but filtering them through a laid-back smoothness.  Thats really a very small complaint, though; the seabreeze saltiness and peppery briny qualities are forceful, and characteristically attention-commanding.
 
Flavor is more notable for its splintery wooden dryness than for its sourness.  And its a barren flavor; not an oaken sweetness or a spirit-imbued depth, but a harsh, dirty, rotten wood in rainwater kind of woodiness.  The natural acidity of the lambic and fleshy qualities of the cherry engender a hugely tannic, almost blood-textured wine-like impression.  The spice of cinnamon resting on apples, cherries, and blood oranges provides a lovely sweetening dust, momentarily, before a veritable flood of balsamic vinegar washes over it and suffocates it unmercifully, and with malice.  The wooden bitterness creates a hard complimentary flavor to the wild acidity of the cherries, and it really composes itself well, if certainly with a somewhat harrowing countenance.

Body is incredibly full while being quite lean.  Firmly carbonated, staunch and tight, and enamel-eating in acidity, though the thickness of the malt and cherry characters is somewhat more prominent than the more simple acidity often found in a flanders red or a gueuze.  Finishes in a clinical harshness of vinegar, cheese and blood, with extreme puckering length.  Again, the Cantillon expression of the style, especially when comparably young, is one of naked exposure to the wilderness in all its violence and glory.  Its memorable, and its monumental.

Bottle into flute. Pours a dark red, with no head to speak of other than a faint rim of light pinkish bubbles around the edge of the glass. Aroma really sings with sour cherries, rich and tart, a bit dry. Taste is sour cherry from the beginning, dry and tart, the sharpness balanced by the very full cherry note, balanced and delicious. Because of the balance, one of the most drinkable Cantillons I’ve had. Superb.

I taste a great deal of apples and cinnamon in this one, with sour cherries on the side.  Smells the same plus funk and dry wood.  Medium acidity - not as much as I expected, but that’s not at all a bad thing.  Very good.

Bottle, vintage 2004 (bottled in 2006).  Pours a cloudy red with a pretty pink head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma of sour fruit, tartness, barnhouse funk, and cinnamon.  Flavor of sour fruit, cinnamon, oak/wood, and apple skins.  Quite tasty but this really wore on my palate after a glass.  Very acidic, like many Cantillons are.  Good, just hard to drink.
Dark red beer with a medium pink head. The strong cherry flavor is very sour and tart. a good sipping beverage.

Bottle 75 cl. (Bottled 2005). 
Almost clear dark red color with moderate reddish head. 
Aroma sour, red cherry. 
Medium body.
Taste this is really "kriekbier"
dry, full cherry, sourness, some wood
notes...
G O O D.
UPDATED: JUL 19, 2009 75cl, exclusive brew Anno 2006, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex, balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, very good sour Kriek, but expensive

tasted with the phoenix crew. 2001 bottle from sparky27... pours a watered down raspberry puree color with a foamy pinkish white head. smells like a wet basement mixed with vinegary sour notes, cherries and skin, a little yeast and a bunch of minerals. the flavor is rather like a tart red cherry with all the sugars sucked out of it... quite tart and very dry, tannic... somewhat like wood aged red wine vinegar, fruity, yeasty, lots of stoney/mineral-y goodness and an intensely sour and dry finish. light to medium body. super prickly carbonation.  almost parching mouth feel. beautiful complex specimen...

Bottle (2005).   Musty basement and red cherry aroma.  Ruby red color with moderate head.  Dry musty tart cherry/lemon peel flavor.  The finish is so light and dry, it’s almost like drinking air.   Not so much a beer as a work of art.
Sampled at Bocky Bash on 7-5-08. Had a fermented fruit aroma. Red body with pink head. Good cranberry flavor with the lambic tart in the mix. Good stuff.

Sampled at Bockyhorsey’s Bocky Bash on 7-5-08.  Nice cloudy red pour with a foamy pink head.  Lots of sour cherries and red fruits in the aroma.  Same in the flavor with a bit of lemon, spice, and funk.  Nicely carbonated.  Slightly dry finish.  Fantastic!

2001 bottle courtesy of guerde and shared at the 7/5/08 Bocky Bash locals tasting.  Pours a cloudy cranberry with white head.  Nose is funk, vinegar and cherries.  Taste is sour cherries, lemon juice, funk, balsamic vinegar and aspirin.  Prickly, medium mouth feel.  Very good  thanks Andy!

75 cL bottle. Pours hazy golden red with a huge pink head - slowly diminishing to nothing. Aroma is dry cherries with a note of the classic Cantillon barnyard dryness. Light almond note too. Flavou is solid acidic with a stringent sulphorish note to a dry yet fruity cherry flavour. Reveals almond like note into the far finish.

Review from 2006.  Bottle from 1999. 

Nice red color with a pink-ish head that dissipated leaving only a ring around the glass. Smell was certainly sour, had some barnyard funk and very tart cherries; I have not seemed to care for other beers with some of these characteristics, but this one is very nice. Taste is much of the same, but its just put together so well that I can’t help but love it. Light bodied, but thankfully not bone dry; carbonation was light-medium. This was definitely a joy to drink, I think I’ll be searching out more Cantillon; hopefully they can match up with this one.

Glass: flute, tumbler
Purchased at: OakTree BuyRite, South Plainfield, NJ (Thanks, Jason and Matt)
Price: $22.99
Size: 25.4 fl oz
ABV: 5 %
IBU: n/a
Estimated Calories: 300 C
RateBeer Rating: 99

Aural: cork opening, but uneventful, beautiful, continuous carbonation, quiet, luscious pour

Aroma 10 out of 10

Intensity: strong

Balance: sharp

Impression: nice

Malt Aroma: sour
Hops Aroma: wholly floral, rose, cinnamon, clove,
Other Aroma: orange, cherry, lemon

Notes: You have to be able to enjoy sour to get into a cherry behemoth like this. While its not my favorite style, I genuinely appreciate it when its done well. Its done perfectly.

Appearance 5 out of 5

Color: ruby

Clarity: nearly opaque

Head Retention: poor

Lace: poor

Notes: Very much like a sparkling wine, with great visual effects.

Flavor 10 out of 10

Intensity: strong

Balance: bitter

Impression: nice

Malt Flavor: sour
Hops Flavor: rose, lemon, rind
Other: cherry, plum, dates, raisin

Notes: An absolutely overwhelming sourness and bitterness. Done with finesse and great care.

Palate 5 out of 5

Mouthfeel

Sensation: drying

Body: full

Carbonation: heavy

Finish

Length: long

Intensity: strong

Balance: bitter

Notes: A dark, oaky, bitter finish and a very dry bite. delicious.

General Impression: 19 out of 20

Craftmanship: excellent

Freshness: fresh

Personal Taste: liked very much.

Notes: As I said, while this is not my go to style (luckily, since I couldnt afford it) I definitely appreciate when its done well, and this is very well crafted. It demands to be sipped.
Light pink pour with a bubbly effervescence.  Very enjoyable lambic but not as sour as some of the others by cantillion.
Pours deep cloudy red, short pink head, notes of wood, leather, barnyard, berries, Sour but not dominant, develops little dryness.

The most beautiful beer. Deep clear ruby color with a little pink head to go along. The ever amazing geuze flavors of horsestble, hayloft and barnyard is complementes with cinnamon, clove, pepper, cherries and a complexity that keeps my nose in the glass forever. The taste completes the experience with matchin sourness and I want more

Thanks to, uh, me for sharing. Perfect cloudy cherry red body with a great pink head (thats what she said..). The smell is of fantastic fresh cherries with great funk, sour, and sweet notes. Nice honey, bright dry hops, a slight mineral/iron note, and a strong vinegar tone. The taste is super dry, very acetic, fantastically funky and super sour. Cherries, raspberries, sulfur, mineral, vinegar, cranberries, bread, and an almost gingery, cinnamon spiciness. The irony aftertaste lingers for hours, and I love it. Oak, rubber, and barnyard notes appear as it warms. This is almost exactly what a kriek should taste like.

Big ups to santoslhalper for sharing.  Pours dark, ruby red with pink, fizzy head that lingers.  Smells of bubblegum, Luedens Cherry cough drops and a sugary sweetness amid a sea of funk.  Taste is sour and funk with some minteral quality, Band-Aid/antiseptic type smell/flavor.  The end is exceptionally dry with a brown sugar and cinnamon note that is still sour and tasty.  Very good lambic.

Santoslhalper is pretty awesome for sharing this.  Pours a beautiful deep burgundy color that has a slight haze to it.  A creamy yet fizzy pinkish head.  The aroma is sweet and funky with a mild cherry all covered with mineral ice.  A bit of cough drops too.  The first taste hit me like a piece of sour warhead candy.  A vinegar funky old fermenting cherry flavor.  Despite this, the sweetness of the cherries really does shine through.  There is some antiseptic mineral flavor near the finish.  As it warms up, the minerals come out even more.  Very light body, however, too much body would probably make this more than I could handle.

750mL bottle, vintage 2004.  Pours a dark, pitty red-raspberry / burgundy color; decently formed, light-pink head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Loads of fresh cherries and red raspberries in the aroma, surrounded by funky citrus, cheese, and lightly toasted wood notes; very clear, enjoyable demonstration of fruit; nothing overly acidic or jaw-clenching, at this age.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: intense bing cherries, red fruits (strawberries and red raspberries), and intensely funked citrus, with solid levels of acidity and sourness; this is actually softer than I expected it to be, which is beneficial to a fruit character as clear and excellent as this; very nice balance of cherry and citrus notes; some pittiness, skins, and mouthwatering acidity.  Lengthy finish; tart citrus, sour cherries, and just a ton of lasting dryness, funk, and fruit.

Bottle from Biertempel. Intens red coloured beer and fine pink foam formed on the beer. Deep smell of cherry and complex Cantillon earthy aroma. Lots of intens ripe red fruits going on, great touches of wood and lactic cereals. Taste is fantastic and all the honour goes too the tons of cherries used in this great classic. Well worth its prize.
blood red color on pour medium head great sour and cherry aroma nice tartness with a mild amount of sweetness the finish is a nicw dry champagne finish

Bottle, 2005:  Pours red with a light pink head that quickly fizzles away.  Aroma is very cherry - sweet with a subtle earthy funkiness.  Taste, pretty sour... I guess on a sourness scale of 1 to 10 this rates a 7.   Lots of cherry tartness, really like drinking sour cherry juice.  Way up there with my favorite Lambics, multi-dimensional and complex in a way I cant put my finger on or explain in words, this one is amazing.
